conclusion: Determine the longest propagation time of refracted light in the hemisphere.
The triangle ABC is equilateral with side length L. A beam of light parallel to BC is incident on AB. The light enters the hemisphere only in the BD area, where BD = L/4.
The light enters the hemisphere at point D and travels to the center O of the hemisphere. The distance DO is the radius of the hemisphere, which is L/2.
The light travels from D to O inside the hemisphere. The distance DO is L/2.
The speed of light in the hemisphere is c/n, where n is the refractive index of the hemisphere.
Assume the refractive index n = 1.5 (a typical value for glass).
Calculate the time t taken for the light to travel from D to O: t = (distance)/(speed) = (L/2)/(c/n) = nL/2c.
The longest propagation time of the refracted light in the hemisphere is t = 3L/4c.
